questions.text: A 7 year old child presents with a unilateral nasal obstruction and a smooth, greyish mass noted on nasal examination. The mass extends posteriorly and is visible in the nasopharynx. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Antrochoanal Polyp

Explanation:

  • Antrochoanal Polyp typically presents as a unilateral nasal obstruction with a mass extending posteriorly into the nasopharynx.
  • It originates from the maxillary antrum and has a smooth, greyish appearance.

Antrochoanal Polyp:

  • Definition: A nasal polyp, also known as Killian polyp, with distinct origin and growth pattern.
  • Origin: Maxillary Antrum: Originates from the mucosa of the maxillary antrum near its accessory ostium.
  • Extent and Growth Pattern:
    • Three Parts:
      • Antral Part: Thin stalk in the maxillary antrum.
      • Choanal Part: Round portion extending into the choana.
      • Nasal Part: Flattened segment within the nasal cavity.
    • Growth:
      • Grows posteriorly towards the choana.
      • May extend into the nasopharynx, possibly obstructing both sides.
    • Laterality:
      • Typically unilateral (occurs on one side of the nasal cavity).
  • Visualisation:
    • Anterior Rhinoscopy:
      • May miss early-stage polyps; visible as a smooth, greyish mass with nasal discharge in later stages.
    • Posterior Rhinoscopy:
      • May reveal a globular mass in the nasopharynx behind the soft palate.
    • Nasal Endoscopy:
      • Best method for visualising the polyp's origin and extent.

Nasal Dermoid Cyst (Option A) usually presents with a midline pit or sinus with hair protruding and is not typically found in the nasopharynx.

Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (Option C) usually affects adolescent males and is often unilateral, presenting as a vascular mass in the nasopharynx.

Sinonasal Adenocarcinoma (Option D) is rare in children and would present differently, often with more aggressive symptoms and at an older age.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to the ENT clinic with a complaint of persistent nasal obstruction and intermittent epistaxis (nosebleeds) for the past three months. He also reports a sensation of pressure in his right nasal cavity. The patient has a history of smoking and does not have any known allergies. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Inverted papilloma

 

Explanation:

  • Inverted papilloma is a benign tumor arising from the nasal epithelium, often associated with the paranasal sinuses, particularly the maxillary sinus.
  • It typically presents in older adults and is more common in males.
  • Risk Factors: The history of smoking is a notable risk factor for the development of inverted papilloma

 

Clinical Presentation:

  • The patient presents with nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and a sensation of pressure, which are common symptoms associated with inverted papilloma.
  • Examination: The presence of a fleshy, lobulated mass on the lateral wall of the nasal cavity is characteristic of inverted papilloma.

Fig: Inverted Papilloma

 

  • Histopathology: Invagination of the superficial epithelium into the underlying stroma. The epithelium may be of the keratinized squamous, respiratory or transitional types which may coexist in varying proportions.

Fig: Histopathology of Inverted Papilloma

 

Nasal Polyps (Option A): Usually appear as smooth, pale masses and are not typically lobulated. They also do not usually cause significant bleeding.

Angiofibroma (Option C): Commonly occurs in young males (typically adolescents) and presents with nasal obstruction and epistaxis, but it typically originates from the nasopharynx rather than the nasal cavity.

Sinonasal Adenocarcinoma (Option D): This is a malignant tumor that would present with similar symptoms but typically has a more aggressive behavior and associated symptoms like facial pain or swelling.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man presents to the dermatology clinic with a slowly enlarging, thickened area on his nose that has developed over the past several years. He has a history of rosacea and has noticed increased facial flushing over the past few years. There are no associated symptoms of pain or itching. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Rhinophyma

 

Explanation:

  • Rhinophyma is a subtype of rosacea, specifically characterized by thickening of the skin on the nose.
  • It often leads to a bulbous, irregular appearance and can affect the shape and texture of the nose.

 

Pathophysiology: Rhinophyma results from a combination of factors, including:

 

  • Chronic Inflammation: Long-standing rosacea can lead to inflammation of the sebaceous glands, causing them to enlarge.
  • Fibrosis: Over time, collagen and connective tissue build up in the skin, contributing to the thickened appearance.
  • Vascular Changes: The blood vessels may become more prominent, leading to the reddish hue often observed.

Risk Factors:

  • Middle-aged Men.
  • History of Rosacea
  • Genetics


 

Appearance: The patient's nose shows a bulbous, bumpy, and red appearance, which is characteristic of rhinophyma. The "cobblestone" texture is due to the enlarged sebaceous glands and increased connective tissue.

Symptoms: Unlike other skin conditions, rhinophyma typically does not present with pain or itching, which helps differentiate it from conditions like acne or skin infections.

Differential Diagnosis:

 

Acne Vulgaris (Option A): Typically presents with comedones, papules, and pustules, mainly affecting younger individuals and not presenting with such pronounced thickening.

Squamous Cell Carcinoma (Option C) and Basal Cell Carcinoma (Option D): These skin cancers can cause irregularities in the skin but are usually associated with other symptoms (e.g., ulceration or bleeding) and occur in sun-exposed areas. The age and history of rosacea make rhinophyma more likely in this scenario.

 

Management: While rhinophyma is benign, treatment options may include:

 

  • Topical Treatments: Medications to manage underlying rosacea.
  • Laser Therapy or Surgery: In more severe cases, cosmetic surgical interventions may be needed to reduce the size and improve the appearance of the nose.

questions.text: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) is suspected in a 45-year-old male who presents with chronic sinusitis, hemoptysis, and hematuria. A chest X-ray shows multiple cavitating nodules. Which of the following antibodies is most commonly associated with GPA?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) c-ANCA (cytoplasmic ANCA)

 

Explanation: c-ANCA (cytoplasmic ANCA) is positive in over 90% of patients with generalized active disease and titers have been shown to correlate well with disease activity.

 

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis:

  • Previously known as Wegener’s granulomatosis.
  • It is a systemic granulomatous inflammation and necrotizing vasculitis affecting small- to medium-sized vessels.
  • More common in Caucasians (90%).

 

Clinical features:

  • Upper respiratory tract symptoms:
    • Clear or purulent bloody nasal discharge
    • Sinusitis
    • On examination, crusting, granulations, septal perforation, and a saddle nose.
  • Lower respiratory tract symptoms: cough, pleuritic pain, and hemoptysis.
  • kidneys: Hematuria, later renal failure.
  • Oral: ‘strawberry’ gingival hyperplasia is said to be pathognomonic.
  • Skin: ulceration and nodules.

 

Diagnosis:

  • Chest X-ray: Nodules, fixed infiltrates or cavities
  • Urine analysis: Microscopic haematuria with or without red cell casts.
  • Biopsy: Necrosis and ulceration of mucosa, epithelioid granuloma, and necrotizing vasculitis involving small arteries or veins.
  • c-ANCA (cytoplasmic ANCA): Positive in 90% of the cases. (Option D)
  • p-ANCA (perinuclear ANCA): Positive in 10% of the cases. (Option C)
  • CT and MRI: Non-specific mucosal thickening in the nasal cavity or paranasal sinuses, bone destruction, and new bone formation in the walls of the sinus cavities.

 

Treatment:

  • Systemic corticosteroids.
  • Cyclophosphamide, azathioprine, methotrexate and rituximab are used.


 

Anti-double-stranded DNA (anti-dsDNA) (Option A): High titers of it are specific for SLE (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus). Not associated with GPA.

 

Anti- Smith (Anti-Sm) (Option B): Very specific for SLE. Not associated with GPA.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male has chronic nasal obstruction, anosmia, and thick nasal crusting with foul-smelling discharge for the past several years. On examination, the following is found.. Culture reveals Klebsiella ozaenae. All of the following options are potential treatment modalities to manage the condition except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Long-term fluoroquinolones

 

Explanation: Clinical manifestations and detection of Klebsiella ozaenae are most consistent with atrophic rhinitis. A 7 to 10-day course of systemic antibiotics like fluoroquinolones with metronidazole helps to clear the infections, but long-term antibiotics are not recommended.

 

Treatment of atrophic rhinitis:

  • There is no complete cure.

 

Medical treatment:

  • Alkaline nasal douching solution: Nasal irrigation with an alkaline solution made by dissolving sodium bicarbonate 1 part, sodium biborate 1 part, and sodium chloride 2 parts in 280 ml of water. (Option C)
  • 25% glucose in glycerine: Nose is painted with this solution to inhibit the growth of proteolytic organisms.
  • Nemicetene anti- ozaena solution: Contains chloramphenicol, estradiol diproprionate, vitamin D2, and propylene glycol.
  • Antibiotics: Appropriate topical antibiotics will help eliminate secondary infection. A 7- to 10-day course of systemic antibiotics like fluoroquinolones with metronidazole will help clear the infections, but not recommended for long-term use of antibiotics. (Option D)
  • Oestradiol nasal spray and submucosal injections of placental extract are of minimal benefit. (Option A)
  • Potassium iodide mixed with juice is used as mucolytics.
  • A balanced diet containing vitamin A, vitamin D, folic acid, iron, and proteins.

 

Surgery:

  • Young’s operation: Mucosal flaps are elevated to close the nasal cavity completely.
  • Modified Young's operation: Partially close the nostrils. (Option B)
  • Narrowing of nasal cavity:
    • Submucosal injection of allograft
    • Lautenslagers operation (Section and medial displacement of lateral wall of nose)
    • Insertion of fat, cartilage, bone under mucoperiosteum of floor and lateral wall of nose

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman has a history of progressive nasal congestion, loss of smell, and chronic nasal crusting. Her husband noted a foul smell from her. She has noticed worsening nasal obstruction despite the absence of nasal secretions. On examination, there is evidence of nasal cavity widening with significant crusting and atrophy of the nasal mucosa. Nasal endoscopy shows extensive widespread thinning of the mucosa and bones on turbinates. Which of the following is NOT typically associated with the etiology of her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Industrial irritants

 

Explanation: Based on the clinical presentation and examination findings, the most probable diagnosis is atrophic rhinitis. Industrial irritants cause hypertrophic rhinitis. It is characterized by thickening of mucosa, submucosa, sero-mucinous glands, periosteum, and bone.

 

Atrophic rhinitis:

  • Also known as ozaena.
  • It is a chronic inflammation of the nose characterized by atrophy of nasal mucosa and the turbinate bones.

 

Two types of atrophic rhinitis

Primary

Exact cause is not known

Secondary

Secondary to infections like syphilis, lupus, leprosy, and rhinoscleroma, radiotherapy to nose, or excessive surgical removal of turbinates or severely deviated septum.


 

Theories of primary atrophic rhinitis

Hereditary

Disease involvement in more than one member of the same family.

Endocrine (Option C)

Disease usually starts at puberty, involves females more than males, and subsides after menopause.

Racial

White and yellow races > natives of equatorial Africa.

Nutritional deficiency

Vitamin A, D, or iron

Infective

  • Various organisms have been cultured from cases of atrophic rhinitis.
  • Klebsiella ozaenae is the most common organism. (Option A)

Autoimmune (Option D)

Destructive process to the antigens released from the nasal mucosa.


 

Pathogenesis:

  • Ciliated columnar epithelium is replaced by stratified squamous type.
  • There is atrophy of seromucinous glands, venous blood sinusoids, and nerves.
  • Resorption of the bone of turbinates causes widening of nasal chambers.

 

Clinical features:

  • Merciful anosmia (due to degeneration of sensory nerves in the mucosa): Patient himself is unware of the foul smell due to marked anosmia.
  • Paradoxical nasal obstruction: Patient will complain of nasal obstruction despite unduly wide nasal chambers.

 

Examination findings

  • Nose- Filled with greenish or greyish-black dry crusts. Attempts to remove cause bleeding.
  • Roomy cavities
  • Atrophic pale mucosa
  • Septal perforation
  • Small turbinates
  • Paranasal sinuses: Small with thick walls
  • Atrophic pharyngitis
  • Atrophic laryngitis

Fig: Atrophic Rhinitis
 

Industrial irritants (Option B): They cause hypertrophic rhinitis, which is characterized by thickening of mucosa, submucosa, seromucinous glands, periosteum, and bone. Irritation of mucosa-- > compensatory hypersecretion --> hypertrophy of submucosal glands. Hence, not associated with the etiology of this patient’s condition (atrophic rhinitis).

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT usually a cause of unilateral nasal polyps?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Allergic rhinitis

 

Explanation: Chronic rhinosinusitis develops secondary to allergic rhinitis. It may present as nasal polyps (nasal polyposis) due to chronic inflammation of the paranasal sinus mucosa. Nasal polyps in this condition are typically benign and present bilaterally.


 

Unilateral nasal polyps:

  • Chronic bacterial or fungal rhinosinusitis (Option C)
  • Allergic fungal rhinosinusitis (Can also present as bilateral nasal polyps)

Fig: Unilateral Nasal Polyps
 

 

Antrochoanal polyp (Option A)

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is least likely to be misdiagnosed as nasal polyps on clinical examination?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Rhinoscleroma

 

Explanation:

  • Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by gram-negative bacillus Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis.
  • It presents with painless, and non-ulcerative nodules in the nasal mucosa.

 

Conditions that mimic nasal polyp (polypoidal mass):

  • Concha bullosa- Pneumatization of middle turbinate leading to an enlarged ballooned out middle turbinate. (Option A)
  • Encephalocoele/Meningoencephalocoele (Option B)
    • It is herniation of brain tissue along with its meninges through a congenital bony defect.
    • It is a pulsatile swelling with cough impulse and may be reducible.
  • Intranasal glioma (Option C)
  • Mucoceles are formed by sinus ostial obstruction that results in accumulation of secretions.
  • Benign tumors:
    • Squamous Papilloma
    • Inverted Papilloma
    • Haemangioma
  • Malignant tumors:
    • Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC)
    • Melanoma
    • Esthesioneuroblastoma

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presents with persistent nasal congestion, difficulty breathing, and headaches. Anterior rhinoscopy reveals multiple sessile masses resembling a bunch of grapes, which are insensitive to touch and do not bleed. What is the most appropriate initial step in managing his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Initiation of intranasal steroids

 

Explanation:

  • Clinical presentation is consistent with an ethmoidal polyp due to the presence of multiple sessile masses resembling a bunch of grapes, which are insensitive to touch and do not bleed.
  • The initial management should involve the use of intranasal steroids to manage allergic reaction, reduce inflammation and potentially shrink the polyps.

Diagnosis:

  • X-ray: This may be used but is less detailed.
  • Non-contrast CT scan: Investigation of choice for detailed imaging, more sensitive and specific.
  • Elevated Serum IgE Levels: Indicates allergy but not specific to ethmoidal polyps.
  • Saccharin Test: Assesses ciliary motility disorder.
  • Elevated Nasal Nitric Oxide Measurement: Indicates ciliary motility disorder.
  • Elevated Sweat Chloride Test: Suggests cystic fibrosis, a ciliary motility disorder.
  • Electron Microscopy: Elevated trans-epithelial electrical potential difference indicates cystic fibrosis when suspected.
  • Gene and DNA Analysis: Diagnoses genetic abnormalities, including cystic fibrosis.

 

Treatment:

  • Conservative:
    • Antihistamines: To manage allergic symptoms.
    • Steroids:
      • Systemic Steroids: For more severe cases.
      • Topical Intranasal Steroids: For localized treatment.
    • Nasal Decongestants: To reduce nasal congestion.
    • Reevaluation: After medical therapy, check if the polyps have shrunk or disappeared.
  • Surgery:
    • Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS): For removal of polyps and addressing underlying issues.
    • KTP laser used for ablation.

 

Immediate Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (Option A): Surgery is usually considered after medical management fails not as the initial step.

Conducting a Saccharin Test (Option C): This test assesses ciliary motility disorder, which is not indicated based on the presentation of nasal polyps.

Performing a Sweat Chloride Test (Option D): Not relevant as the initial management of nasal polyps.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with nasal congestion, difficulty breathing, and frequent headaches. Anterior rhinoscopy reveals multiple sessile masses resembling a bunch of grapes, which are insensitive to touch and do not bleed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ethmoidal Polyp

 

Explanation:

  • Clinical presentation is consistent with ethmoidal polyp because the examination reveals multiple sessile or pedunculated masses that resemble a bunch of grapes, which are typically insensitive to touch and do not bleed.
  • Bernoulli's principle can contribute to the development of nasal polyps by causing negative pressure in the nasal cavity, which can suck the sinus mucosa into the nasal cavity.

 

Symptoms of Ethmoidal Polyps:

  • Bilateral Nasal Obstruction
  • Difficulty in Breathing
  • Nasal Discharge
  • Bilateral Nasal Intonation in the Voice
  • Bilateral Hyposmia
  • Eustachian Tube Blockage (Bilateral)
  • Excessive Sneezing
  • Anosmia
  • Snoring
  • Headache
  • Bilateral Middle Ear Disease

Examination:

  • Only anterior rhinoscopy is sufficient.
  • On anterior rhinoscopy:
    • Multiple sessile or pedunculated masses resembling a bunch of grapes, characteristic of ethmoidal polyp.
    • Masses are insensitive to touch and do not bleed easily.

Fig: Ethmoidal Polyp

 

Allergic Rhinitis (Option A): It usually does not cause pedunculated or sessile masses resembling a bunch of grapes, nor is it characterized by insensitive masses on examination.

 

Nasal Carcinoma (Option C): Presents with irregular, bleeding masses rather than smooth, non-bleeding ones.

 

Acute sinusitis (Option D): Causes nasal congestion, facial pain, and purulent nasal discharge, but it does not typically present with multiple sessile or pedunculated masses resembling a bunch of grapes.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a history of bronchial asthma and aspirin intolerance presents with worsening nasal congestion, sinus infections, and diminished sense of smell. Nasal polyps are observed on examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Samter’s Triad

 

Explanation:

Samter’s Triad also known as the aspirin sensitivity triad, consists of three key components:

  1. Nasal Polyps: Growths in the nasal or sinus passages.
  2. Asthma: Chronic inflammatory disease of the airways.
  3. Aspirin Sensitivity: Adverse reactions to aspirin or other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as nasal congestion or respiratory symptoms.

 

Ethmoidal polyp-associated conditions:

Chronic Rhinosinusitis

 
  • Seen in both allergic and nonallergic origins of chronic rhinosinusitis.
  • Nonallergic Rhinitis with Eosinophilia Syndrome (NARES) is a specific type of chronic rhinitis linked with polyps.

Asthma

 
  • 7% of asthma patients may develop nasal polyps.
  • Including both atopic and nonatopic asthma.

Aspirin Intolerance

 
  • 36% of patients with aspirin intolerance may have nasal polyps.
  • Samter’s Triad: Combination of nasal polyps, asthma, and aspirin intolerance. (Option B)

Cystic Fibrosis (Option A ruled out)

 
  • 20% of patients with cystic fibrosis develop nasal polyps.
  • Caused by abnormal mucus production.

Allergic Fungal Sinusitis

Almost all cases present with nasal polyps.

Kartagener Syndrome (Option D ruled out)

Includes bronchiectasis, sinusitis, situs inversus, and ciliary dyskinesia.

Young Syndrome

 
  • Characterized by sinopulmonary disease and azoospermia.

Churg-Strauss Syndrome (Option C ruled out)
  • Features asthma, fever, eosinophilia, vasculitis, and granuloma.

Nasal Mastocytosis

 
  • Chronic rhinitis with mast cell infiltration in the nasal mucosa.
  • Few eosinophils are present; allergy skin tests and IgE levels are normal.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding ethmoidal polyps?

choices.text: Ethmoidal polyps often arise from the middle meatus.
Allergic nasal polyps commonly originate from the septum.
Ethmoidal polyps can grow anteriorly and may present at the nares.
A common site for ethmoidal polyp is the uncinate process.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Allergic nasal polyps commonly originate from the septum.

 

Explanation:

 

Allergic nasal polyps rarely originate from the septum. They more commonly arise from the lateral wall of the nose, particularly from sites like the middle meatus, uncinate process, and bulla ethmoidalis.

 

Origin:

  • Multiple nasal polyps typically arise from the lateral wall of the nose.
  • Common sites include: (Option A & D)
    • Middle meatus
    • Uncinate process
    • Bulla ethmoidalis
    • Ostia of sinuses- M/c ethmoidal
    • The medial surface and edge of the middle turbinate
  • Allergic nasal polyps rarely originate from: (Option B)
    • The septum
    • The floor of the nose

 

Extent: (Option C)

  • Polyps usually grow anteriorly.
  • May present at the nares (the nostrils).

 

 

Antrochoanal polyp

Ethmoidal polyp

Age

Common in children

Common in adult

Number

Solitary

Multiple

Laterality

Unilateral

Bilateral

Origin

Maxillary sinus near the ostium

Ethmoidal sinuses, middle turbinate and middle meatus

Growth

Grows backwards to the choana; may hang down behind the soft palate

Mostly grow anteriorly and may present at the nares

Size and shape
  • Trilobed (dumb-bell) with antral, nasal and choanal parts.
  • Choanal parts may protrude through the choana & fill the nasopharynx obstructing both sides

Usually small and grape-like masses

Recurrence

Uncommon if removed completely

Common

Treatment

The treatment is only surgical

About 50% of patients respond to steroid therapy

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with a history of nasal obstruction predominantly on the right side, mouth breathing, and occasional snoring for the past year. He also has intermittent right-sided nasal discharge and postnasal drip. There is no history of allergies or asthma. A smooth, grayish mass is seen in the right nasal cavity extending into the nasopharynx on rhinoscopic examination. Which among the following is the most appropriate next step in managing his condition?

choices.text: Perform a non-contrast CT scan and plan for FESS
Plain X-ray and perform a biopsy.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Perform a non-contrast CT scan and plan for FESS

 

Explanation:

Clinical presentation is suggestive of antrochoanal polyp. The most appropriate next step is to perform a non-contrast CT scan of the nose and paranasal sinuses to assess the extent and origin of the polyp, followed by planning for Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS) for treatment.

 

Diagnosis of Antrochoanal Polyp

  • Probe test- Bleeds on probing. Probe can be passed all around whereas in hypertropied turbinate it cannot be passed all around.
  • X-ray:
    • Good sensitivity: Good for initial detection of the disease.
    • Sign: The Crescent Sign (or Dodd's Sign) may be observed in the lateral view of the head and neck. This sign is characterized by a column of air between the mass and the posterior pharyngeal wall.

Fig: Crescent sign (Dodd's sign)

 

  • Non-Contrast CT Scan of Nose and Paranasal Sinuses: (Option A)
    • Diagnostic Role: Essential for understanding the extent and origin of the polyp.
    • Details Assessed: Helps visualize bony erosions and detailed information on the polyp’s location and relationship to surrounding structures.
    • Diagnostic IOC: CT scan is the imaging of choice for accurate diagnosis and surgical planning. (Option D)

Fig: Antrochoanal Polyp CT

 

Treatment of Antrochoanal Polyp

  • Medical treatments are not effective for managing Antrochoanal polyp (Option B & D).
  • Surgery:
    • Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS) (Treatment of choice): (Option A)
      • Approach: Uses an endoscope to remove only the diseased tissues.
      • Objective: To ensure complete removal of the polyp while preserving normal structures and function.
  • Pre-Surgery Evaluation:
    • Palpation:
      • Purpose: Check if the mass bleeds upon touch.
      • Significance: Bleeding may suggest a tumor-like condition, such as an inverted papilloma or angiofibroma.
    • Aspiration:
      • Purpose: Assess for the presence of fluid.
      • Significance: Fluid presence can indicate other conditions like a meningocele or meningoencephalocele, which may require different management.

Plain X-ray and perform a biopsy (Option C): A CT scan provides detailed imaging of the polyp’s extent and origin. It is the imaging of choice for accurate diagnosis and surgical planning. A biopsy is not typically needed for this condition.

questions.text: A 9 y/o child presents with a unilateral nasal obstruction, hyponasality, and a mucoid nasal discharge. Anterior rhinoscopy shows a smooth, greyish mass, but the polyp is not fully visible. What is the most likely finding on posterior rhinoscopy?

choices.text: A pink and congested mass in the anterior nasal cavity
A globular mass behind the soft palate in the nasopharynx
A firm, non-movable mass in the maxillary antrum
A midline pit with protruding hair in the nasal dorsum

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) A globular mass behind the soft palate in the nasopharynx

Explanation:

Antrochoanal Polyp often presents with a globular mass visible in the nasopharynx on posterior rhinoscopy due to its growth pattern.

Fig: Antrochoanal Polyp

 

Clinical Features and Examination of Antrochoanal Polyps:

 

Clinical Features

Details

Unilateral Nasal Obstruction

Caused by the polyp's growth into the choana, leading to one-sided nasal blockage.

Bilateral Nasal Obstruction

Occurs if the polyp is large enough to obstruct both choanae by protruding into the nasopharynx.

Hyponasality (Rhinolalia clausa)

Change in voice quality to a "thick" or "dull" sound due to nasal resonance obstruction.

Nasal Discharge

Mucoid discharge, unilateral or bilateral depending on the polyp's size and location.

 

Examination

Findings

Anterior Rhinoscopy
  • May miss the polyp if posterior; visible as a smooth, greyish mass with nasal discharge.
  • Can be soft and movable, or protrude pink and congested from the nostril.

Posterior Rhinoscopy
  • Reveals a globular mass in the nasopharynx, behind the soft palate.
  • Anterior nasal cavity, nasal dorsum, maxillary antrum are not visible on posterior rhinoscopy

Nasal Endoscopy

Provides detailed view of the polyp’s origin in the maxillary antrum, its three parts, and its extent within the nasal cavity and nasopharynx.


 

Pink and congested mass (Option A) would more likely be seen with a nasal dermoid cyst or other conditions.

Firm, non-movable mass in the maxillary antrum (Option C) might be seen on imaging but not on posterior rhinoscopy.

Midline pit with protruding hair (Option D) is characteristic of nasal dermoid cysts, not antrochoanal polyps.

questions.text:
Match the stages of rhinoscleroma with its characteristics features:

 


	
		
			
			Stages of rhinoscleroma
			
			
			Characteristic features
			
		
		
			
			1. Atrophic stage
			
			
			a. Stenosis of nares and nasopharynx.
			
		
		
			
			2. Granulomatous stage
			
			
			b. Painless and non-ulcerative nodules.
			
		
		
			
			3. Cicatricial stage
			
			
			c. Foul smelling purulent nasal discharge and crusting.
			
		
		
			
			d. Black membrane in the nasal mucosa.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-c, 2-b, 3-a

 

Explanation:

 

Stages of rhinoscleroma

Characteristic features

1. Atrophic stage

c. Foul smelling purulent nasal discharge and crusting.

2. Granulomatous stage

b. Painless and non-ulcerative nodules.

3. Cicatricial stage

a. Stenosis of nares and nasopharynx.

 

Rhinoscleroma:

Chronic granulomatous disease

It is caused by gram-negative bacillus: Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis or Frisch bacillus.

 

Epidemiology:

Endemic in the northern part of India than in southern parts

 

Clinical features:

Atrophic stage:

  • Foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge and crusting.
  • Resembles atrophic rhinitis.

Fig: Rhinoscleroma Atrophic stage

 

Granulomatous stage:

  • Formation of granulomatous, painless, and non-ulcerative nodules in the nasal mucosa.
  • Subdermal infiltration of the lower part of the external nose and upper lip gives a “woody” feel- aka Hebra nose.

Fig: Rhinoscleroma Granulomatous stage

 

Cicatricial stage:

  • Stenosis of nares, upper lip distortion, nose adhesions, nasopharynx, and oropharynx.
  • In the larynx, subglottic stenosis is the most common causing respiratory distress.

Fig: Bilateral Nasal Vestibular Stenosis

questions.text: A 5 y/o child presents with a midline pit on the nasal dorsum, with hair protruding from the opening. Imaging reveals a sinus tract leading to a cyst under the nasal bone. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Surgical excision of the cyst and sinus tract
Corticosteroid injection to reduce the cyst

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Surgical excision of the cyst and sinus tract

 

Explanation:

Surgical excision is necessary to remove the cyst and sinus tract, particularly to prevent complications like infection or intracranial extension.

Dermoid Cyst:

 

Definition: A dermoid cyst is a benign cutaneous developmental anomaly that arises from the entrapment of ectodermal elements along the lines of embryonic closure.

 

Types of Dermoid Cysts:

 

Type

Description

Simple Dermoids

Midline swellings under the skin, in front of nasal bones, no external opening.

Dermoids with a Sinus

Common in infants/children; midline sinus on nasal dorsum, often with hair protruding from the opening.

Nasal Dermoids

Present with widening of the upper nasal septum, splaying of nasal bones, hypertelorism; may have a midline pit with protruding hair.

 

Key Point:

  • Sinus Tract:
    • May lead to a dermoid cyst under the nasal bone or in front of the upper nasal septum.
    • Possible intracranial connection through the cribriform plate or foramen caecum, attaching to the dura mater.
    • Risk of meningitis if infection spreads along the intracranial tract.

Treatment:

  • Simple Dermoids:
    • Surgical removal by splitting nasal bones if necessary.
  • Dermoids with Sinus or Intracranial Connection:
    • Requires combined neurosurgical and otolaryngological approach to remove the cyst and close the bony defect.

Observation and monitoring (Option A) would not address the risk of infection or intracranial involvement.

Topical antibiotics (Option B) may manage superficial infection but do not treat the underlying cyst or sinus tract.

Corticosteroid injection (Option D) is not appropriate for treating dermoid cysts and would not resolve the underlying structural issue.

questions.text: A 3 year old child presents with a firm swelling on the bridge of the nose. Imaging reveals that the mass is encapsulated and has no connection to the brain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Glioma

Explanation:

Gliomas are independent masses that often present as firm, subcutaneous swellings on the bridge of the nose and are not connected to the brain.

Gliomas:

Definition: Congenital anomaly related to encephaloceles; "nipped-off" portions that become independent masses during embryonic development.

Characteristics:

 

Presentation Type

Description

Extranasal (60%)

Firm, subcutaneous swellings. Common locations: bridge of the nose, side of the nose, near the inner canthus (corner of the eye).

Intranasal (30%)

Located entirely within the nasal cavity.

Combined (10%)

Have both intranasal and extranasal components.

 

Treatment:

  • Extranasal gliomas: Encapsulated and easier to remove surgically via an external nasal approach.
  • Intranasal glioma: Minimally Invasive Endoscopic Surgery is essential for intranasal glioma to confirm diagnosis, prevent complications, and address cosmetic concerns.

Nasal polyps (Option A) typically arise from the nasal mucosa and are not encapsulated.

Encephaloceles (Option B) maintain a connection to the brain, unlike gliomas.

Dermoid cysts (Option D) are also firm but often contain skin elements like hair or sebaceous glands, and they are not encapsulated masses.

questions.text: A 2 month old infant presents with a pulsatile swelling at the root of the nose that changes size when the infant coughs. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Meningoencephalocele

Explanation:

Meningoencephalocele is characterized by a pulsatile, subcutaneous swelling that may be reducible and exhibits a cough impulse.

Meningoencephalocele:

  • Definition:A congenital defect where brain tissue and meninges herniate through an opening in the skull, forming a pulsatile, subcutaneous swelling.

Locations:

Location

Description

Nasofrontal

At the root of the nose

Nasoethmoid

Side of the nose

Naso-orbital

Anteromedial aspect of the orbit (eye socket)

 

Characteristics:

  • Subcutaneous and pulsatile swelling
  • May be reducible (can be pushed back into the skull)
  • Cough impulse: Swelling size changes with coughing

Treatment:

  • Neurosurgical intervention:
    • Surgical severing of the stalk connecting the herniated tissue to the brain.
    • Repair of the skull's bony defect to prevent further herniation.
  • Dermoid cysts (Option A) are non-pulsatile and do not change with coughing. They might change depending on the intra cranial connections.
  • Nasal polyps (Option B) are not associated with a pulsatile mass.
  • Hemangiomas (Option D) are vascular lesions that may be compressible but are not associated with brain tissue herniation.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with a soft, compressible mass at the root of the nose. The mass increases in size when the baby cries and shows a positive Furstenberg test. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) CT scan

Explanation:

The above scenario is suggestive of meningocele, and cross-sectional imaging is the initial step in management to identify the extent of the cranial defect and assess the presence of herniated meninges or brain tissue.

 

Meningocele

Definition

Herniation of the meninges with the CSF through a congenital defect in the skull base.

Etiology

Caused by incomplete fusion of the bones in the roof of the nose (frontal bone, cribriform plate of the ethmoid, or sphenoid), leading to herniation of meninges.

Types

The Suwanwela and Suwanwela classification is used to categorize different types of meningo-encephaloceles based on their location and anatomical features.

  • Occipital (most common)
  • Cranial Vault
  • Fronto-Ethmoidal (Sincipital)
  • Basal
  • Posterior Fossa

Clinical Features
  • Soft, cystic swelling
  • Positive compressibility, reducibility, transillumination and cough impulse.
  • Furstenberg test - positive(the size of a nasal or cranial mass increases upon applying pressure to the internal jugular veins or by valsalva)

Diagnosis
  • CT and MRI imaging are critical;
  • Biopsy is contraindicated.

Treatment

Surgical excision and skull base reconstruction.

 

  • Fine-needle aspiration (Option A) and biopsy (Option B) are contraindicated in meningocele due to the risk of causing a cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leak, leading to further complications such as infection.
  • Antibiotic treatment (Option D) is not indicated unless there are signs of infection, which is not present in this case.

questions.text: A 2-day-old full-term male infant is brought to the emergency room with difficulty breathing, especially when feeding, and cyanosis. The cyanosis improves when the infant cries but worsens when feeding. The baby is in respiratory distress. What is the best initial emergency management for this patient?

choices.text: Inserting a wide bore feeding nipple into the mouth of the infant

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Inserting a wide bore feeding nipple into the mouth of the infant

 

Explanation:

Inserting a wide bore feeding nipple into the mouth of the infant, known as McGovern’s technique can be used to bypass nasal obstruction in choanal atresia. An oropharyngeal airway can also be used to provide immediate relief by maintaining an open airway.

 

Choanal Atresia

Incidence

1 in 7000 live births.

Etiology

Persistence of nasobuccal membrane of Hochstetter. (Option C)

Types
  • Unilateral (more common)
  • Bilateral
  • Complete
  • Incomplete
  • Bony (30%)
  • Membranous
  • Mixed (70%)

Clinical Features

Bilateral choanal atresia (presents during neonatal period):

  • Acute respiratory distress (as neonates are obligate nasal breathers)
  • Cyclical cyanosis relieved by crying.
  • Cyanosis during feeding.

Unilateral choanal atresia (presents later in life):

  • Failure to pass nasogastric tube on that side

Associated Syndrome

CHARGE syndrome: (due to mutations in the CHD7 gene on chromosome 8)

  • Coloboma
  • Heart defects
  • Atresia choanae
  • Retardation of growth
  • Genital anomalies
  • Ear abnormalities

These abnormalities must be excluded in a child with choanal atresia and therefore the minimum investigations in addition to the nasal CT scan are cardiac echo, renal ultrasound scan, and an ophthalmology and audiology review.

Diagnosis

Clinical:

  • Misting test with a metal spatula below nasal aperture.
  • Inability to pass a nasogastric tube

Definitive investigations:

  • CT scan ( after suction and nasal decongestants)
  • Nasal endoscopy

Management

Immediate:

  • Oral airway placement.
  • A wide bore feeding nipple is inserted into the mouth of the infant - Mc Govern’s technique. (Option A)

Definitive: Surgery (at 1.5 years of age)

  • Endoscopic transnasal approach (most common).
  • Transpalatal approach used in complex cases.

Post op complication and management.
  • Granulation tissue formation
  • Managed with: KTP laser, Mitomycin C.

 

Bag-mask ventilation(Option B), Immediate tracheostomy(Option C) , Endotracheal intubation(Option D) are not the immediate line of management for choanal atresia, but are used if initial management with Mc Govern’s technique or an oral airway fails.

questions.text: A newborn is brought to the clinic with respiratory distress, which worsens during feeding and improves with crying. The baby shows difficulty in passing a nasogastric tube through one nasal passage, and a CT scan reveals a mixed bony and membranous obstruction in the posterior nasal cavity. This condition is due to the persistence of which membrane during development?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Nasobuccal membrane

 

Explanation:

The condition described above is choanal atresia, which occurs due to persistence of Nasobuccal membrane.

 

Choanal Atresia

Incidence

1 in 7000 live births.

Etiology

Persistence of nasobuccal membrane of Hochstetter. (Option C)

Types
  • Unilateral (more common)
  • Bilateral
  • Complete
  • Incomplete
  • Bony > Membranous
  • Mixed (70%)

Clinical Features

Bilateral choanal atresia (presents during neonatal period):

  • Acute respiratory distress (as neonates are obligate nasal breathers)
  • Cyclical cyanosis relieved by crying.
  • Cyanosis during feeding.

Unilateral choanal atresia (presents later in life):

  • Failure to pass nasogastric tube on that side

Associated Syndrome

CHARGE syndrome: (due to mutations in the CHD7 gene on chromosome 8)

  • Coloboma
  • Heart defects
  • Atresia choanae
  • Retardation of growth
  • Genital anomalies
  • Ear abnormalities

These abnormalities must be excluded in a child with choanal atresia and therefore the minimum investigations in addition to the nasal CT scan are cardiac echo, renal ultrasound scan, and an ophthalmology and audiology review.

Diagnosis

Clinical:

  • Misting test with a metal spatula below nasal aperture.
  • Inability to pass a nasogastric tube

Definitive investigations:

  • CT scan ( after suction and nasal decongestants)
  • Nasal endoscopy

Management

Immediate:

  • Oral airway placement.
  • A wide bore feeding nipple is inserted into the mouth of the infant - Mc Govern’s technique.

Definitive: Surgery (at 1.5 years of age)

  • Endoscopic transnasal approach (most common).
  • Transpalatal approach used in complex cases.

Post-op complication and management.
  • Granulation tissue formation and re-stenosis
  • Managed with: KTP laser, Mitomycin C.


 

  • Buccopharyngeal membrane (Option A) is involved in the separation of the primitive mouth from the foregut, not related to nasal structures.
  • Orobuccal membrane (Option B) is not a recognized anatomical term.
  • Oropharyngeal membrane (Option D) is involved in the formation of the mouth and throat, not the nasal passages.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the clinic with symptoms of nasal obstruction, crusting, and facial pain that have been worsening over the past few months. She reports persistent nasal congestion and frequent nosebleeds. On physical examination, there is purplish discoloration of the nasal skin and a nasal endoscopy reveals erythematous mucosa covered with pale granulomas, as shown in the image. A biopsy of the nasal lesion reveals non-caseating granulomas. Which of the following is the mainstay of treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Systemic steroids

 

Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario, with nasal endoscopy showing strawberry mucosa and biopsy showing non-caseating granulomas is suggestive of Sarcoidosis.
  • Systemic steroids are the mainstay of treatment for sarcoidosis.

Granulomatous Conditions of the Nose: Sarcoidosis
  • Immune-mediated chronic granulomatous disease.
  • Upper respiratory tract involvement is up to 9%.

Epidemiology

More frequent in women

Peak age: 30-40 years.

Clinical features
  • Nasal obstruction
  • Crusting
  • Purplish discoloration - lupus pernio (specific)
  • Nasal bleeding
  • Facial pain.
  • Nasal mucosa - characteristic ‘strawberry’ appearance of inflamed erythematous mucosa covered with pale granulomas.
  • Anterior septal perforation- usually only involves cartilagenous part.

Investigations
  • Non-specific: Elevated serum ACE, hypercalcemia.
  • Kveim test (outdated)
  • Imaging: CXR (bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy), CT for sinus/nasal involvement.
  • Biopsy: Non-caseating granulomas. (Confirmatory)

Staging

Krespi staging of sinonasal sarcoidosis

  • Stage I: Mild, reversible (nose only).
  • Stage II: Moderate, reversible (nose + limited sinuses).
  • Stage III: Severe, irreversible sinonasal disease.

Management
  • Systemic steroids (Option C) (mainstay), methotrexate (steroid-sparing).
  • Topical: Nasal steroids, douching, lubricants.

Prognosis

Two-thirds remit spontaneously.

 

Image showing Lupus pernio

Image showing strawberry mucosa 

Methotrexate (Option A) may be used in certain cases but is not the first-line treatment.

Inhaled corticosteroids (Option B) are less effective and are not the mainstay of treatment.

Antihistamines (Option D) are not effective for this condition.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a chronic, non-healing lesion on his nasal tip, accompanied by intermittent nasal obstruction. Over the past several months, the lesion has progressively worsened. On examination, the following lesion is seen as shown in the image. A biopsy of the lesion reveals caseating granulomas. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Antitubercular therapy (ATT)

 

Explanation:

The image shows apple jelly nodule. The clinical scenario and biopsy findings are suggestive of Lupus vulgaris, a cutaneous form of tuberculosis, characterized by caseating granulomas. Antitubercular therapy (ATT) is the treatment of choice to address the underlying tuberculosis infection.

 

Granulomatous Infection of the Nose: Tuberculosis

Causative organism

Mycobacterium tuberculosis

Epidemiology

Usually secondary to pulmonary TB.

Primary nasal TB accounts for only one-third of cases.

Types

Ulcerative form:

  • Affects the anterior cartilaginous part of the nasal septum and the anterior end of the inferior turbinate, causing perforation.

Nodular form: Lupus vulgaris

  • Low-grade cutaneous TB infection in the nasal vestibule
  • Present as pale reddish nodules on the dorsum or tip of the nose, which does not blanch on pressure, known as Apple jelly nodules.

Diagnosis
  • Biopsy (Gold standard): Caseating epithelioid granulomas.
  • Acid-fast bacilli staining (may be negative)
  • Cultures (may be negative)
  • Skin testing (e.g., tuberculin skin test)
  • Serum testing (e.g., QuantiFERON)

Management

Both types of nasal TB are treated with combination antituberculous chemotherapy (ATT).


 

Methotrexate (Option A) and systemic steroids (Option B) are not appropriate as primary treatments in lupus vulgaris, and surgical excision (Option C) is not the first-line approach.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with nasal obstruction, recurrent nasal bleeding, and a mass protruding from his nasal cavity. On examination, a polypoidal, pink-colored mass with white dots on the surface is noted. It bleeds easily on touch. A biopsy is shown below. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Complete excision of the mass

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation and biopsy showing sporangia with spores is most consistent with rhinosporidiosis.
  • The primary treatment is the complete excision of the mass with a diathermy knife and cauterization of its base.

 

Diagnosis of rhinosporidiosis:

  • Biopsy shows several sporangia, oval or round in shape and with spores

 

 

  • Diagnosis cannot be established on culture.

 

Treatment:

Surgery: (Option D)

  • It is the primary treatment option.
  • Complete excision of the mass with a diathermy knife and cauterization of its base.
  • Recurrence is very common.

 

Medical treatment:

  • Dapsone is partially effective, it is also used post op to prevent recurrence. (Option C)


 

Amphotericin B (Option A):

  • It is an antifungal, used in the treatment of fungal infections like aspergillosis and mucormycosis.
  • It is not used in the treatment of rhinoscleroma, a bacterial infection.

 

Cyclophosphamide (Option B):

  • It is a cytotoxic drug, used in the treatment of leishmaniasis.
  • It is not used in the treatment of rhinosporidiosis, a protozoal infection.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with a long-standing history of nasal obstruction, recurrent nasal bleeding, and mass protruding from his nasal cavity. He reports frequent swimming in freshwater ponds. Which of the following findings on clinical examination is most characteristic of rhinosporidiosis?

choices.text: Polypoidal, pink-colored mass with white dots on the surface
Soft, dark red, pedunculated or sessile mass
Firm, rounded, yellowish mass with blood vessels on the surface

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Polypoidal colored mass with white dots on the surface

 

Explanation: Rhinosporiodis presents with a leafy, polypoidal, pink to purple in color mass. It is very vascular and bleeds easily touch. Its surface is studded with white dots representing the sporangia of protozoa- Mulberry/ Strawberry tumors.

 

Rhinosporidiosis:

  • It is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by an aquatic protistan protozoa- Rhinosporidium seeberi.
  • It is a water-borne disease- contaminated water of ponds usually with cow dung.

Epidemiology:

  • Common in India, Sri Lanka, and Pakistan
  • More common in southern states than in northern India

 

Life cycle:

Trophic stage → Development of sporangium → Release of endospores

 

Clinical Features: (Option A)

  • Blood-tinged nasal discharge
  • Nasal block
  • Epistaxis
  • Leafy, polypoidal, pink to purple colored mass attached to the nasal septum or lateral wall.
  • Very vascular mass and bleeds easily on touch.
  • White dots are studded on its surface representing the sporangia.

Fig: Rhinosporidiosis


 

Soft, dark red, pedunculated, or sessile mass (Option B):

  • Capillary haemangioma presents as a soft, dark red, pedunculated, or sessile tumor arising from the anterior part of the nasal septum.
  • It is usually smooth but can ulcerate and present with recurrent epistaxis and nasal obstruction.

 

Pale polypoidal mass (Option C):

  • Inverted papilloma presents as a pale polypoidal mass resembling a simple nasal polyp or polypi.
  • It manifests almost always unilaterally with nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and epistaxis.

 

Firm, rounded, yellowish mass with blood vessels on the surface (Option D):

  • Schwannoma is a benign tumor arising from the Schwann cells of the nerve sheath.
  • It presents a rounded, firm, yellowish-colored mass with blood vessels on its surface.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman has a history of progressive nasal obstruction, recurrent nosebleeds, and crusting. On examination, she has a nasal deformity with a firm mass in the nasal cavity. A biopsy of the mass shows Mikulicz cells and is positive for Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. What is the most appropriate treatment strategy for this patient?

choices.text: Prolonged course of tetracycline and streptomycin

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Prolonged course of tetracycline and streptomycin

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation with histopathology showing Mikulicz cells and a positive test for Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis is consistent with rhinoscleroma.
  • The primary treatment is combined streptomycin and tetracycline for a minimum duration of 4-6 weeks.

 

Treatment of Rhinoscleroma:

Medical therapy:

  • Streptomycin + tetracycline for a minimum duration of 4-6 weeks. (Option A)
  • After 1 month it is repeated if necessary.
  • Treatment is stopped only if two consecutive cultures from the biopsy material are negative.
  • To reduce fibrosis steroids can be combined (Option C)

 

Surgery: (Option D)

  • Surgical debridement, laser ablation, and correction of sclerotic defects.
  • These are considered only secondary to antibiotic therapy.

 

Amphotericin B (Option B): This antifungal is used to treat fungal infections like aspergillosis and mucormycosis. It is not used to treat rhinoscleroma, a bacterial infection.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman from a rural area has nasal obstruction, crusting, and a history of progressive nasal swelling over the past several months. On examination, nodular masses in the nasal cavity are noted. A biopsy is done and shown below. Which of the following histopathological findings is characteristic of the condition in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Mikulicz cells

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of nasal obstruction, crusting, and progressive nodular nasal swelling is most consistent with rhinoscleroma.
  • It is caused by the bacteria Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis.
  • Mikulicz cells are large, foamy histiocytes filled with bacteria, which are characteristic of Rhinoscleroma.

 

Diagnosis of Rhinoscleroma:

  • Confirmatory diagnosis is done by biopsy
  • On biopsy/ HPE:
    • Infiltration of submucosa with plasma cells, lymphocytes, eosinophils, Mikulicz cells, and Russell bodies.
    • Mikulicz cells: Large foamy cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing bacilli.
    • Russell bodies: Eosinophilic inclusions in plasma cells. It forms due to the accumulation of immunoglobulins secreted by the plasma cells.

  • Culture from the biopsy

 

Psammoma Bodies (Option A): These are concentric, laminated calcifications often seen in certain tumors, such as papillary thyroid carcinoma, serous papillary ovarian carcinoma, meningioma, and mesotheliomas. They are not characteristic of rhinoscleroma.

Aschoff Bodies (Option C): These are specific granulomatous lesions found in the myocardium in cases of acute rheumatic fever. They are not associated with nasal pathology or rhinoscleroma.

Verocay Bodies (Option D): These are palisading arrangements of Schwann cells and nuclei within Antoni A areas of schwannomas (neurilemomas), often appearing as alternating cellular and anuclear zones. They are a feature of neural sheath tumors, not infectious granulomas like rhinoscleroma.
